chapter.title: Alias Targets
chapter.para: We've already seen how you can use &f-Alias; to create a target named install:

scons_example.name: alias_ex1
scons_example.file: env = Environment() hello = env.Program('hello.c') env.Install('__ROOT__/usr/bin', hello) env.Alias('install', '__ROOT__/usr/bin')

chapter.para: You can then use this alias on the command line to tell &SCons; more naturally that you want to install files:

Like other &Builder; methods &Alias; returns an object representing the alias being built. You can use this object as input to another &Builder;. This is especially useful if you use such an object as input to another call to the &Alias; &Builder;, allowing you to create a hierarchy of nested aliases:

scons_example.name: alias_ex2
scons_example.file: env = Environment() p = env.Program('foo.c') l = env.Library('bar.c') env.Install('__ROOT__/usr/bin', p) env.Install('__ROOT__/usr/lib', l) ib = env.Alias('install-bin', '__ROOT__/usr/bin') il = env.Alias('install-lib', '__ROOT__/usr/lib') env.Alias('install', [ib, il])

chapter.para: This example defines separate install, install-bin, and install-lib aliases, allowing you finer control over what gets installed:
